the tourniquet pouch is supposed to be a separate item as well

description: A compact nylon pouch for first aid items.  There is a separate bottom pocket for a tourniquet.

variants.description: A compact, folding nylon pouch for first aid items, such as bandages.  Two plastic inserts inside can hold a variety of different items, including pill bottles, secured in place by a cord.  There is a separate pocket for a tourniquet, hanging at the bottom of the pouch.  <variant_multicam>

A compact, folding nylon pouch for first aid items, such as bandages.  Two plastic inserts inside can hold a variety of different items, including pill bottles, secured in place by a cord.  There is a separate pocket for a tourniquet, hanging at the bottom of the pouch.  <variant_multicam_black>

A compact, folding nylon pouch for first aid items, such as bandages.  Two plastic inserts inside can hold a variety of different items, including pill bottles, secured in place by a cord.  There is a separate pocket for a tourniquet, hanging at the bottom of the pouch.  <variant_black>

A compact, folding nylon pouch for first aid items, such as bandages.  Two plastic inserts inside can hold a variety of different items, including pill bottles, secured in place by a cord.  There is a separate pocket for a tourniquet, hanging at the bottom of the pouch.  <variant_ranger>

notes: height is assumed to be half of what the pouch is capable of, judging by the photos
there are supposed to be two of these inserts in the pouch

allows items to slightly exceed size of insert

notes: height is assumed to be half the height of pouch
there are supposed to be two of these inserts in the pouch

description: A large nylon pouch for carrying one's gas mask.  Designed to take in a variety of gas masks, in a pinch it can be used as an impromptu dump pouch.  This model can attach to webbing or be worn at the leg.

variants.description: A large nylon pouch for carrying one's gas mask, as issued to U.S. Marine Corps.  Designed to take in a variety of gas masks, in a pinch it can be used as an impromptu dump pouch.  This model can attach to PALS webbing or be worn at the leg.  <variant_coyote>

A large nylon pouch for carrying one's gas mask, as issued to U.S. Marine Corps.  Designed to take in a variety of gas masks, in a pinch it can be used as an impromptu dump pouch.  This model can attach to PALS webbing or be worn at the leg.  <variant_olive>

notes: height is presumed thickness of two walls of the pouch
dimensions acquired from visual reference

description: A nylon pouch for storing 40mm grenades.  Could also be used to store other types of grenades, like 37mm, flashbangs, smoke, and so on.

variants.description: An open-top nylon pouch for storing 40mm grenades.  Could also be used to store other types of grenades, like 37mm, flashbangs, smoke, and so on.  Like many other pouches, this one flattens out when not filled.  <variant_multicam>

An open-top nylon pouch for storing 40mm grenades.  Could also be used to store other types of grenades, like 37mm, flashbangs, smoke, and so on.  Like many other pouches, this one flattens out when not filled.  <variant_black>

An open-top nylon pouch for storing 40mm grenades.  Could also be used to store other types of grenades, like 37mm, flashbangs, smoke, and so on.  Like many other pouches, this one flattens out when not filled.  <variant_ranger>

//notes: this pouch is 'tall', and thus able to reliably hold extended-capacity box magazines
description: A nylon pouch for a single rifle magazine.  Will fit many, though not all, rifle magazines.

variants.description: A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine.  When stored, 30-round standard magazines poke out of the top, where it's secured with an elastic band.  This pouch design makes it that much faster to use than a closed-top design with a flap.  Has PALS webbing on the front, fit for the same pouch or something smaller.  <variant_multicam>

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine.  When stored, 30-round standard magazines poke out of the top, where it's secured with an elastic band.  This pouch design makes it that much faster to use than a closed-top design with a flap.  Has PALS webbing on the front, fit for the same pouch or something smaller.  <variant_black>

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine.  When stored, 30-round standard magazines poke out of the top, where it's secured with an elastic band.  This pouch design makes it that much faster to use than a closed-top design with a flap.  Has PALS webbing on the front, fit for the same pouch or something smaller.  <variant_coyote>

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine.  When stored, 30-round standard magazines poke out of the top, where it's secured with an elastic band.  This pouch design makes it that much faster to use than a closed-top design with a flap.  Has PALS webbing on the front, fit for the same pouch or something smaller.  <variant_ranger>

description: A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine and a single pistol magazine.  Not as quick to use as two separate pouches, but takes up fewer slots on the webbing.

variants.description: A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine and a single pistol magazine.  When stored, standard-length magazines poke out of the top.  Rifle magazines are secured with an elastic band, while pistol magazines are covered with a flap.  This design trades some quickness of use for covenience, since it allows you to carry magazines for both your rifle and your backup pistol in less space than two separate pouches would take.  <variant_multicam>

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine and a single pistol magazine.  When stored, standard-length magazines poke out of the top.  Rifle magazines are secured with an elastic band, while pistol magazines are covered with a flap.  This design trades some quickness of use for covenience, since it allows you to carry magazines for both your rifle and your backup pistol in less space than two separate pouches would take.  <variant_black>

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine and a single pistol magazine.  When stored, standard-length magazines poke out of the top.  Rifle magazines are secured with an elastic band, while pistol magazines are covered with a flap.  This design trades some quickness of use for covenience, since it allows you to carry magazines for both your rifle and your backup pistol in less space than two separate pouches would take.  <variant_coyote>

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine and a single pistol magazine.  When stored, standard-length magazines poke out of the top.  Rifle magazines are secured with an elastic band, while pistol magazines are covered with a flap.  This design trades some quickness of use for covenience, since it allows you to carry magazines for both your rifle and your backup pistol in less space than two separate pouches would take.  <variant_olive>

plus weight of 8 rounds of ball .45 ACP: 331 gr (= 21.448 g = 22 g) × 8 = 171.59 g ≈ 172 g

pocket_data.//min_item_length: slightly shorter than length of pouch (3.65 in. ≈ 92 mm)
//max_item_length: 5.1 in., slightly longer than loaded M1911 mag

//flags: replaced PALS_MEDIUM with PALS_SMALL (aligns with other single-rifle-magazine pouches)

//notes: it appears as though the shell holder is not inherent to the pouch or is removable
photos of the pouch show a 5.56mm insert inside the pouch
we model the pouch as if the shell holder is inherent and the listed ammo are compatible with it in some fashion
description: A long nylon pouch, intended to hold up to 12 shotgun shells.  The flap keeps the shells shielded from the elements.

description: A small nylon pouch for storing a single hand grenade.  This model is quick to operate because it uses a hook-and-loop flap instead of a plastic buckle.

variants.description: A small nylon pouch, intended for storing a single standard-issue hand grenade.  Can also fit a single grenade of slightly-larger volume.  Unlike most models on the market, this one is relatively quick to operate, because it uses a hook-and-loop strap, rather than a plastic buckle.  There's a thin thread outline of an M67 grenade on the flap, and a print that says "FRAG OUT!" on the opposite side of it.  <variant_multicam>

description: A set of six rifle magazine pouches in a single pouch.  Named so because it has two rows of pouches stacked over one another.  The front row is quicker to use, but doesn't hold larger magazines.

variants.description: A set of six sewn-together STANAG magazine pouches.  The front row is noticably shorter, so while these pouches are quicker to draw from, they don't allow larger-than-standard magazines in.  Each front pouch has its own small PALS webbing.  <variant_multicam>

A set of six sewn-together STANAG magazine pouches.  The front row is noticably shorter, so while these pouches are quicker to draw from, they don't allow larger-than-standard magazines in.  Each front pouch has its own small PALS webbing.  <variant_black>

has an interior separator inside the main pocket, which it didn't seem wise to model, since there's no way to separate volume of main pocket from volume of separator 'pocket' without breaking something about pocket management for the player
unlike many other pouches, this one can be worn directly over the shoulder
description: A small nylon bag.  Can be worn over the shoulder or strapped to webbing.  Has plenty of pockets.

Best used on an expedition where you may not need a lot of ammo, but would require food, drink, medication, or other short-term supplies.  <variant_multicam>

description: A pair of nylon grenade pouches sewn together.  Slightly slower to operate than the alternatives.

variants.description: A pair of small nylon bags sewn together, each holding a single standard-issue hand grenade. description: A compact pouch for storing small tools.  Can be attached to webbing and carried on your backpack or load-bearing vest.

//weight: the item's listing offers several different statements on its weight
we err on the side of US-centric measurements, since those hadn't been (aggressively) adjusted to look nice

pocket_data.//max_contains_volume: volume of an iPhone 11 Pro (as mentioned in the listing), +10% since the smartphone didn't occupy the entire pocket

//max_contains_volume: trim is 50%, to account for the pocket not being able to stretch to 0.7 in. across the entire pocket
trim is 50%, to account for the pocket not being able to stretch to 0.7 in. across the entire pocket
0.3 in., the thickness of an iPad
trim is 12.5%, to account for the pocket not being able to stretch to 0.7 in. across the entire pocket
0.2 in., slightly smaller than the full-width pocket
trim is 12.5%, to account for the pocket not being able to stretch to 0.7 in. across the entire pocket
by width and thickness, it appears to fit exactly the Leatherman Skeletool CX
we use 80% of the pouch's height (= 7.04 in.) for length, in order to emulate enabling easy access to the pouches behind the straps
pocket_data.//min_item_length: half of height of the pocket = 3.52 in.

//max_contains_volume: we take the average of width between the small and the large back straps: (2.72 + 1.24) / 2 = 1.98 in.
we use 0.52 in. as the thickness, to keep to parity with the other types of back straps
we use 80% of the pouch's height (= 7.04 in.) for length, in order to emulate enabling easy access to the pouches behind the straps
pocket_data.//min_item_length: half of height of the pocket = 3.52 in.

//max_contains_volume: by width and thickness, it appears to fit the Otterbox power bank well
we add 0.1 in to the thickness in order to bring it to parity with the small back strap
we use 80% of the pouch's height (= 7.04 in.) for length, in order to emulate enabling easy access to the pouches behind the straps
pocket_data.//min_item_length: half of height of the pocket = 3.52 in.

//max_contains_volume: by width and thickness, it appears to fit the Benchmade 42 balisong well
we use 60% of the pouch's height (= 5.28 in.) for length, because this is a smaller-capacity pocket
pocket_data.//min_item_length: half of height of the pocket = 2.64 in.

//max_contains_volume: we model this pocket type's capacity after the small back strap, but limit its length to the typical front strap (60% of total height of the pouch = 5.28 in.)
pocket_data.//min_item_length: half of height of the pocket = 2.64 in.

description: A bunch of strong magnets encased in plastic.  Can be worn on webbing.  Intended for breachers to stash their shotguns away on a mission.

variants.description: A Kydex body holding four strong magnets inside.  MSRS stands for "magnetic shotgun retention system", as it was originally designed to securely hold breaching shotguns.  The "holster" can, of course, hold any weapon made of a ferromagnetic material.  <variant_olive>

A Kydex body holding four strong magnets inside.  MSRS stands for "magnetic shotgun retention system", as it was originally designed to securely hold breaching shotguns.  The "holster" can, of course, hold any weapon made of a ferromagnetic material.  <variant_olive>

//weight: very-roughly estimated from assumed weights of constituent parts
Kydex has the density of only 1.35 g/mL, making it lightweight, and there isn't that much of it, so if we assume ~40 mL of Kydex across the entirety of the holster, it amounts to 54 g

notes: length and width are assumed from visual reference, based on the Molle-Lok attachment's dimensions
thickness is presumed
trim presumes the uneven parts eventually even out with the overall shape

//material: iron is for neodymium, the presumed material for the magnets
the magnet in DDA is made from cast iron, whereas its actual material is stated to be alnico, an iron alloy
